CHANGE.ITEM: *Proofed title page(s). *Reviewed structure. *Checked division-marking material at heads and feet of divisions (HEADS, CLOSER, OPENER, ARGUMENT, EPIGRAPH, SIGNED, BYLINE, etc.). *Added TYPEs to DIVs in order to validate. *Checked for N=""s. *Checked s. *Checked placement and completeness of PBs. *Checked for foreign, damage and missing-page GAPs, #, --. *Checked for LBs, startqs / endqs, q;s, {que}s, ABBRs and Qs. *Checked for FIGUREs and decorated initials. *Checked proofsheets and made corrections found there. *Corrected s and s etc. *Converted s to GAP DESC="illegible" RESP="[vendor name]". *Revalidated.

DIV1.P: As it is performed, at the THEATRE-ROYAL, IN COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: Printed, for G. KEARSLY, W. GRIFFIN, J. COOTE, T. LOWNDS, and W. NICOLE.

DIV1.HEAD: To the READER.
DIV1.P:
THE Editor of the following piece thinks proper to observe, that the first idea of it was conceived, and the plan in some measure executed by a gentleman in Dublin, for the pri∣vate entertainment of some persons of distinction in that kingdom, at a time, when Italian Burlettas were blended with the exhibitions of the Theatre, and almost triumphed over the best productions in our language. The public spirit of those, for whom it was originally intended, prevailed upon the author to enlarge his design. Ac∣cordingly, MIDAS adventured on the stage, and met with uncommon suc∣cess for a series of nights. The Edi∣tor begs leave to add a word con∣cerning the stile which prevails in the following scenes. They are written in the true spirit of the mock-heroic. BURLESQUE, in all times, from the stage of ATHENS down to the DRAGON OF WANTLEY, has been esteemed one of the provinces of the Drama. It's
humour principally consists in making dignified personages raise in our minds trite and ordinary ideas, or else in giving to trivial objects a serious air of gravity and importance.

It would be impertinent to point out instances in either way of compo∣sition; but thus much was deemed necessary that no one should look for another sort of entertainment than was here intended. The public, with their usual candour, will consider the par∣ticular scope of this piece, and will decide nothing till they have heard the musick, to which it is adapted. Should MIDAS in the representation be found to have merit, and indeed, excellence in its kind; the generous critick will allow the author that degree of ap∣plause, which his talents seem to de∣serve.

DIV1.HEAD: Dramatis Personae.
DIV1.P: SCENE, first on mount Olympus, afterwards on the pastures of Lydia.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.
DIV2.STAGE: The curtain rising discovers the Heathen Deities, seated amidst the clouds, in full council: they address Jupiter in chorus, accompanied by all the instruments.
AIR I. King of Prussia's March. Chorus of all the Gods.

L.HI: Earth's globe is but his taw.

SP.SPEAKER: Jup
SP.L: Immortals, you have heard your plaintive sovereign
And Culprit Sol's high crimes. Shall we who govern
Brook spies upon us? Shall Apollo trample
On our commands? we'll make him an example.
As for you, Juno, curb your prying temper, or
We'll make you to your cost, know,—we're your emperor,
Your husband—when the jealous Gad-bee twitches,
Swallow your spittle—Jove will wear the breeches.
SP.STAGE: AIR II. To its own tune.

L.HI: 'Tis a curse to be too knowing
Best let things take their chance.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno
SP.L: What new rape is toward? To sixes and sevens,
This tyrant, for it's sake, will jumble the heavens.
I'll take the law. (to Jup.) My proctor, with a summons
Shall cite you, sir, t'appear at Doctor's Commons.

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.L: Let him—but first I'll chase from Heaven yon varlet,

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.L: What, for detecting you and your vile harlot?
Fine scheme! banish the Sun! drive out Apollo!
That you, of lawless love, deep draughts may swallow.
You'll then not need, thou grand monarque of Horners,
Skulk with your misses into holes and corners.

L.HI: Thus to wrong my chaste love,
For spite of your rakehelly godhead
Nor be, of dues nuptial, defrauded.
In vain you in darkness enclose them,

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.L: Peace termagant, I swear by Styx—our thunder
Shall hurl him to the earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Momus.
SP.L: Sire, we knock under.
Ha, ha, ha, (Aside) O jest most precious!
'Twill serve a thousand years hence to refresh us.
I say, down with him, Jove—exert your puissance,
Morbleu, the puppy's grown a public nuisance,
Ay, ay, short work—put out the light, and then—
SP.STAGE: AIR V. There was a jovial Beggar.

L.HI: For lewd, or chaste, or foul, or fair,

LG.L: When a sporting all may go, may go, may go, &c.

L.HI: Screen'd from the husband's jealous eyes,
All love, all free as air,
No wanton need to fear surprize
Oh what a life were there!
Then hey for trumps, for matadores
Old maids will fly, when past amours,

SP.SPEAKER: Jove.
SP.L: O brave, we nod his doom!

SP.SPEAKER: Apollo.
SP.L: Hold, hold, have patience
Papa—No bowels far your own relations!

LG.L: What can this hurly-burly, this helter-skelter mean?
Jove looks confounded surly!—Chaos is come again.

SP.STAGE: AIR VI. To It's own tune.

L.HI: Maugre your bolts, and wise head,
The world will think you mad.
What worse can Bacchus teach men,
Then break the lamps, beat watchmen

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.L: You saucy scoundrel—there sir—come Disorder,
Down Phoebus, down to earth, we'll hear no farther.

LG.L: Roll, thunders, roll, blue lightnings flash around him,
The blab shall find our sky can do without him.

DIV2.STAGE: Thunder and lightning. Jupiter darts a bolt at him, he falls.—Jupiter re-assumes his throne, and the Gods all ascend together, singing the ini∣tial chorus. Jove in his chair, &c.

SCENE A Champaign country with a distant village; violent storm of thunder and lightning. Shepherds sleeping in the field are rouzed by it and run away fright∣ed. One leaves his cloak, hat, and guittar behind him. Apollo is seen whirling in the air, as cast from heav'n; he falls to earth, with a rude shock, and lies for a while, stunn'd: at length he begins to move, rises, advances, and looking upward, speaks.

SP.SPEAKER: Apol.
SP.L: Zooks! what a crush! a pretty decent tumble!
Kind usage, Mr. Jove—sweet sir—your humble.
Well, down, I am;—no bones broke—tho' sorely pepper'd!
Here doom'd to stay.—What can I do?—turn shepherd.
A lucky thought.—In this disguise, Apollo
No more but Pol, the swain, some flock I'll follow.
Nor doubt I, with my voice, guittar, and person,
Among the nymphs to kick up some diversion.
SP.STAGE: AIR VII. Hang me if I marry.

L.HI: With fun, my disgrace I'll parry
While here on earth, I tarry,
With the nymphs, in my way,
But hang me if I marry—hang me if I marry
Let the sky go to wreck, and miscarry,
To toy, but never marry—toy, but never marry.

SP.SPEAKER: Sileno.
SP.L: Whom have we here! a sightly clown!—and sturdy!
Hum—plays, I see, upon the hurdy-gurdy.
Seems out of place—a stranger,—all in tatters,
I'll hire him—he'll divert my wife and daughters.
—Whence, and what art thou boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: An orphan lad, Sir;
Pol is my name;—a shepherd once my dad, Sir;
I'th upper parts here—tho' not born to serving.
I'll now take on, for, faith, I'm almost starving.

SP.SPEAKER: Selino.
SP.L: You've drawn a prize i'th' lottery.—So have I too;
Why,— I'm the master you could best apply to.
SP.STAGE: AIR VIII. To it's own tune.

L.HI: Since you mean to hire for service
Come with me, you jolly dog,
You can help to bring home harvest,
Tend the sheep, and feed the hog.
With three crowns, your standing wages,
Bacon, beans, salt beef and cabbage,
Come strike hands, you'll live in clover,
When we get you once at home,
We'll all dance to your strum, strum.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: From Nectar, and Ambrosia, 'tis coarse diet;
When I was well, why could I not be quiet.
SP.STAGE: (After a pause takes Sileno by the hand and sings to the foregoing air.)

L.HI: Done, strike hands, I take your offer,
Farther on, I may fare worse,
Zooks, I can no longer suffer,
Do, strike hands; 'tis kind I offer,
I strike hands, and take your offer,
Farther on I may fare worse,
Pity such a lad, should suffer,
Zooks, I can no longer suffer,

DIV2.STAGE: Exeunt, dancing, and singing the chorus.
Daphne and Nysa, discover'd running,—their spin∣ning-wheels over turned.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: But Nysa, how goes on squire Midas' courtship?

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Your sweet Damaetas, pimp to his great worship
Brought me from him a purse;—but the condi∣tions—
—I've cur'd him, I believe, of such commissions.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: The moon-calf! this must blast him with my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.P: Right. So we'er rid of the two frights together.
SP.STAGE: AIR IX. If 'tis joy to wound a Lover.

L.HI: If the swain we sigh for press us,
If the fright we loath address us

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Arch Monkey, hang me if I thought 'twas in you.
Well Ny—work you your Squire—as for my Ninny—
If he shan't curse—then call me driv'ling Gipsey—
The hour that first on Daph he cast a sheep's eye.

L.HI: If I cannot plague the lubber,
Now I have him in my crib,
If, when he begins to blubber,
I can't soothe or laugh, or fib,
Doom'd for life, I may be,
And to wear a slabb'ring bib.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: Ha! ha! ha!—Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Hey-day! what mare's nest's found?—For ever grinning:
Ye rantipoles—is't thus you mind your spinning.

L.HI: And this and that way sidle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Now, dame, and girls, no more let's hear you grumble
At too hard toil:—I chanc'd, just now, to stumble,
On this stout drudge,—and hir'd him—fit for la∣bour.
To'm lad—then he can play and sing and caper.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: He shall not stay—unknown to me to hire him,
A lath!

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Nay there you're out,—no toil can tire him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Gad's me! your distance, scare-crow! cursed civil!
Beggars once mounted, gallop to the devil.
Gaffer, (to Sil.) your blunders every hour surprize one:
This washy clout a drudge!—ah, thou'rt a wise one.
Fine rubbish to bring home, a strolling thrummer!
(to Pol.) What art thou good for? speak, thou ragged mummer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.P: Peace, saucebox, or I'll maul you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Goody, my strength and parts you under value.
For his and your work, I am brisk and handy.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Our Gammer, sure, has tipt her of stingo!
Am I Apollo, and must bear this lingo?
SP.STAGE: AIR XII. A tune in Queen Mab.

L.HI: Pray goody, please to moderate the rancour of your tongue:
Why flash those sparks of fury from your eyes?
Remember, when the judgement's weak, the prejudice is strong.
A stranger why will you despise?

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Sirrah, this insolence deserves a drubbing.

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: With what sweet temper he bears all her snubbing (aside)

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Oons, no more words—go boy, and get your dinner.
Fye, why so cross grain'd to a young beginner?

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: So modest!

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: So genteel!

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Not pert, nor lumpish.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Would he were hang'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Nys. and Daph.
SP.L: La! mother, why so frumpish?

DIV2.STAGE: AIR XIII. To the tune of, Non, Non, vo∣lette n'est paint trompeuse.

L.HI: Mama, how can you be so ill-natured,
To a lad, so limb'd, so feature'd,
Girls, for you my fears perplex me
Wife, in vain you tieze and vex me,
Mama, how can you be so illnatur'd,
Ah, ah, to a lad so limb'd, so featured?
Girls, for you my fears perplex me,
Wife in vain you tieze and vex me
Mama, how can yon be so ill-natured,
Psha, psha, you must not be so ill-natur'd;
Ah, ah, to a lad so limb'd, so featur'd,
T'is my pleasure to give pain.

DIV2.STAGE: Squire Midas discovered in his parlour, smoaking his pipe, lolling in an easy chair. Damaetas wait∣ing at a respectful distance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Nysa, you say, refus'd the guineas British.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Ah! please your worship—she is wond'∣rous skittish.
Out, pimp, said she,—take back to him who sent it, That trash—

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Death!—scorn'd!—the minx shall sore re∣pent it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: She scorns you—

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: But when you told her what I meant to settle—

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: She flounc'd, you'd swear her tongue was of bell-metal.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: I'll have her, cost what 'twill, odsbods—I'll force her—

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: The halter—

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: As for madam, I'll divorce her.—

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: The bishop's court—lard help your paper noddle!
Did she not give the slip to young Sir Dawdle?
Her sitter Daphne too, a curse upon her,
Uses me worse, than Nisa does your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Some favour'd lout incog our bliss op∣poses,

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Ay, Pol, the hind, puts out of joint our noses.
SP.STAGE: AIR XIV. Fanny's fairer than a flower.

L.HI: Wretched he, whose pain or pleasure
Such the merchant's state, whose treasure
Swims the sport of tide and wind.
Shifts her lover, like her smock.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: I've heard of that Pol's tricks,—of his sly tampering
To fling poor Pan, but I'll soon send him scamper∣ing.
An upstart!—rival me!—by George, I'll pheaze him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Sir, he bewitches every girl that sees him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: 'Sblood, I'll commit him—drive him to the gallows!
Where is old Pan?

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Tipling, Sir, at th' ale-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Run, fetch him—we shall hit on some ex∣pedient—
To rout this Pol.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: I fly, (going returns) Sir, your obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: What boots my being Squire
Justice of Peace, and Quorum?
Church-warden—knight o'th' shire,
And Custos Rotulorum?
If saucy little Nysa's heart rebellious,
My squireship slights, and hanckers after fellows?
SP.STAGE: AIR XV. To a French tune, A la Santé du Pere d'Oleron.

L.HI: Shall a paltry clown, not fit to wipe my shoes

LG.L: Shall a peasant minx, when justice Midas wooes

L.HI: Her nose up at him toss?

LG.L: I'll sell her Pol a slave, get mundungus in exchange,

L.HI: So glut to the height of pleasure,

DIV2.STAGE: Pan is discovered sitting at a table, with a tankard, pipes, and tobacco before him, his bagpipes lying by him.

L.HI: He rules the roast in the sky,
Yet he's a fool if he thinks
That he's as happy as I.
And leads his highness a weary life;
And strole a batchelor's merry life.
Yet cringe to his harridan's furbella;
And clink the cannikin here below.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: There sits the old soaker—his pate troubling little
How the world wags—so he gets drink and vittle:
Hoa, master Pan!—Gad you've trod on a thistle!
You may pack up your all, sir, and go whistle.
The wenches have turn'd tail—to yon buck-ranter,
Tickled by his guittar—they scorn your chanter.
SP.STAGE: AIR XVII. Tune in Pant. of Fortunatus

L.HI: All around the maypole how they trot,
There is old Sileno frisks like a mad

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: O blood, and guts! What, dare the tinkler scurvy
Intrude, to turn my wenches topsy turvy?
A fop! chouse me out of my choice trol-lops,
I'll smash his trim guittar—about his chaps.
SP.STAGE: AIR XVIII. My wife's a galloping, &c.

L.HI: Shall he run away with the lasses
By his trills, and his slurs, and his graces,
From me who at fairs, and horse-races,
Have pip'd to the laird of the clan.
A fribble!—If I can but catch him
I'll pummel—I'll pinch, and I'll scratch him,
I warrant I'll make him not match him
Self as a musician with Pan.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Keep yourself cool, good master Pan—this courage
Is thrown away—Pol's a mere chip in Porridge;
Softly and fair—

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: You're right;—our Squire, when mellow,
'Tis he shall do't—he's a rough, hect'ring fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Why he sent me for you—He, with kicks o'th' crupper,
Will make Pol dance—He'll gi'n salt eel to's supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Step you before—I'll but just pay my reck'ning
And in a crack attend his worship's beck'ning.

DIV2.STAGE: He throws some pieces on the table, and de∣parting is met by

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: O Pan! the devil to pay—both my sluts frantic!
Both in their tantrums, for yon cap'ring antick.
Rivals forsooth!

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: What, for a straggling goatherd!

SP.SPEAKER: Mys
SP.L: For this fine piece of work—thanks to my dotard.

L.HI: Sure I shall run with vexation distracted,
To see my purposes thus counter-acted!
This way, or that way, or which way soever,
All things run contrary to my endeavour.
Nursing in bosom a treacherous viper;
Here's a fine dance—but 'tis he pays the piper:.

LG.L: But I'll go seek 'em all—and if I find 'em,
I'll drive 'em—as if Old Nick were behind 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Soa, soa,—don't flounce;
Avast—disguise your fury.
Pol we shall trounce.
Midas is judge and jury.

L.HI: 'Till be cease of your love to be doubtful.
Look one, but row another way.
Says no, to the mitre that would fill his wish up▪
And swallows him up at a mouthful.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Out on't, I'll act above-board—I'll ne'er flatter,
Not I—I scorn it—tell me no such matter.
My gossips all would loll their tongues,
To see me with my vengeance trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Ay, but to pay him home those wrongs,
Your transports you must stifle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Srifle!—dye first! shall Mysis stoop to crawling!
No—by my will—these hands should stretch him sprawling.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: You do but put him on his guard by bawling
SP.STAGE: AIR. XXI. Duett. Gavott in Overt. Otho.

DIV2.STAGE: Dance of Satyrs, Fauns, and Dryads.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.
DIV2.STAGE: An old grove, in the midst, the old oracular oak by it self, its boughs decorated with votive wreaths. Enter Sileno alone, a garland in his hand. He seems struck with religious horror at the gloomy solitude. During the symphony he advances timor∣ously, and hangs his garland on a branch:

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Hail, mystic oak!—zooks what a taking
Am I now in!—oh, how I shiver!
I'm in an ague—ha! the very shaking
Of the leaves, throws me all over int'a quaking,—
My wife! I'll ne'er forgive her—
I'm wet as in a river—
Ah! ha! there—what was't gave me a twitch?
It must have been a witch,
Or something diabolic.
Oh, 'tis a foolish frolic.

DIV2.STAGE: (Thunder and lightning—Sileno retires trembling to a corner of the stage, and there falls on his knees with hands uplifted.)
Duett. AIR I. To its own tune.

L.HI: Yet known never to be wrong.
Yet known never to be wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.

L.HI: Is my dame mov'd by the devil

SP.L: That she can't to Pol be civil?

SP.SPEAKER: Ora.
SP.L: To Pol be civil.

L.HI: Say, what means the shrewish fripp'ry
Dinn'ng still that girls are slipp'ry?

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Dupes shall we all by Pol be made.

SP.SPEAKER: Ora.
SP.L: All by Pol be made.

L.HI: If I don't discard the lad.
Oh fye, wooden Oracle, fye for shame
To let me go back as wife as I came.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE. A Wood. A wood, and lawn near Sileno's farm, flocks grazing at a distance,—a tender slow sym∣phony. Enter Daphne, walks about melan∣cholic and silent; at length lays herself down on a bank absorbed in meditation. Nysa watching her.

SP.SPEAKER: Nysa.
SP.L: O ho'! is it so—Miss Daphne in the dumps,
Mum—snugs the word—I'll lead her such a dance
Shall make her stir her stumps.
To all her secret haunts,
Like her shadow, I'll follow and watch her:
And, faith, mamma shall hear on't if I catch her.
SP.STAGE: AIR III. From tree to tree.

L.HI: And scarcely can our own success,
A kind of victory we feel,
Deny'd a real bliss, we steal

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: La! how my heart goes pit-a-pat what thumping
E'er since my father brought us home this bump∣kin.
Heigho!—heigho!—yet why
Mope thus and sigh?
Has not the fellow eyes as well as I?
Gad's heart o' grace I'll pluck up;
Throw myself in his way and pump him,
Appear less starch'd and stuck up.
Then let him guess my meaning by my mumping.
SP.STAGE: AIR IV. To a French tune, Quand on Scait aimer et plair.

L.HI: He's as tight a lad to see to,
As e'er stept in leather shoe
And, what's better, he'll love me too,
And to him I'll prove true blue.
Tho' my sister casts a Hawk's eye
I defy what she can do.
He o'er looked the little Doxy,
I'm the girl he means to woo.
Hither I stole out to meet him,
He'll, no doubt, my steps pursue,
If the youth prove true, I'll fit him;
If he's false,—I'll fit him too.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Think o' the devil—'tis said,
He's at your shoulder—
This wench was running in my head,
And pop—behold her.
Such fair occasions are not met with often,
What if I touch the tender vein,
And whine some melting, plaintive strain
Her heart to soften.
SP.STAGE: AIR V. When on the dear bosom lying.

L.HI: At your feet a tender swain
Prays you will not let him languish,
One kind look would ease his pain.
Did you know the lad who courts you
He not long needs sue in vain;
Prince of song, of dance of sports—you
Scarce will meet his like again.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Sir; you're such an oglio,
Of perfection in folio,
No damsel can resist you:
Your face so attractive,
Limbs so supple and active,
That by this light,
At the first sight,
I could have run and kiss'd you.
SP.STAGE: AIR VI. The priest in his boots.

L.HI: If you can caper, as well as you modulate,
With the addition of that pretty face,

LG.L: Pan, who was held by our shepherds a God o' late;

L.HI: Will be kick'd out, and you set in his place.
His beard so frowsy, his gestures so awkward are
And his bag-pipe has so drowsy a drone,
That if they find you, as I did, no backwarder,
You may count an all the girls as your own.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: I ask but you—and yours I'll be for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: How can I trust?

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: You may, you must.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Vows are brittle,
You'll prove fickle.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: I'll die first.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: That's clever.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: D' you think I'll range:
Against all change,
Your charms are my heart's armour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Pol, Pol, make haste, come hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Death, what a time to call,
Oh! not your old lungs of leather.
B'ye Daph.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: B'ye Pol.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: My charmer.
SP.STAGE: AIR VII. An Italian tune of Pescetti.

DIV2.STAGE: (During the symphony, they take a tender leave and part) Exit. Pol.
Nysa bursts from her lurking place.

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Marry come up, forsooth,
I'st me, you forward vixen,
You choose to play your tricks on?
And could your liquorish tooth
Find none but my sweetheart to fix on?

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Marry come up a gain.
Indeed! my dirty cousin!
Have you a right to every swain?

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Ay, tho' a dozen.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: My minikin miss,—do you fancy that Pol

L.HI: Can ever be caught by an infant's dol?
Can you, miss Maypole, suppose he will fall
In love with the gyantess of Guild-hall?
You will lie 'till your mouldy upon the shelf.
You stump o'th' gutter, you hop o' my thumb,
A husband for you must from Lilliput come,
You stalking steeple, you gawky stag,
Your husband must come from Brobdignag.
I'll humble your vanity mistress Trapes.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: No more of those freedoms miss Nysa, I beg,

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Miss Daphne's, conceit must be lower'd a peg.

L.HI: Do, shew your teeth, spitfire, do, but you can't bite.
This haughtiness soon will he laid in the dirt,

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Good lack! what is come o'er me?
I'm all bewitched, untwisted.
Ah! Cupid, thou'rt a wizard
Thy spells are not to be resisted.
Alas, Daphne, has step'd before me!
Envy and love, devour me.
Pol, doats upon her phiz hard
'Tis that, 'tis that sticks in my gizzard.
Midas appears now twenty times more hi∣deous
Ah, Nysa, what resource?—a cloyster.
Death alive—yet thither must I run,
And turn nun.
Lest hurried by love prodigious
Or lur'd by hope insidious,
I be by Pol undone,
As you'd undo an oyster.
SP.STAGE: AIR IX. A French. tune, Assis sur l'Herbertte.

DIV2.STAGE: Going out, is met by MIDAS, entering.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Turn, tygress, turn; nay fly not—
I have thee at a why not.
How comes it, little Nysa,
That heart to me so icy
Should be to Pol like tinder
Burnt up t'a very cinder?

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Sir, to my virtue ever steady,
Firm as a rock
I scorn your shock,
But why this attack?
A mistress can you lack
Who have a wife already?

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Ay there's the curse—but she is old and sickly;
And would my Nysa grant the favour quickly,
Would she yield now—I swear by the Old Harry
The moment madam's coffin'd—Her I'll marry.

L.HI: When my wife is laid in ground
When my wife's laid in the ground.
Oh how happy should I be
Would little Nysa pig with me.
Would little Nysa pig with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Nysa.
SP.L: Young birds alone are caught with chaff,
But think not, squire, this farce on
Me e're shall pass;
At your base scheme I laugh,
E'er I fall to, the grace
Shall be pronounced by the parson.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Yet take my vows.—

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: I would not take your bond, sir,—

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Half my estate—

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: No, nor the whole,—my fond sir.

L.HI: Ne'er will I be left i'th' lurch,
'Till I'm made a bride i'th' church
Can your palace, plate or coach,
Bridle the tongue of foul reproach?

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Well, master Pol I'll tickle,
For him, at least, I have a rod in pickle:
When he's in limbo
Not thus our hoity toity miss
Will stick her arms a kimbo.

L.HI: Steals slily, your poultry to ravage, to ravage.
All's fair to destroy the fell savage, fell savage.
No means do I scruple to banish, to banish.
By hook, or by crook he shall vanish, shall vanish.

DIV2.STAGE: Going out, he is met by PAN.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: So squire, well met.—I flew to know your business.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Why, Pan, this Pol we must bring down on his knees.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: That were a feat indeed!—a feat to brag on.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Let's home—we'll there concert it o'er flagon.
I'll make him skip—

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: As St. George did the dragon.

L.HI: Let his shoulder feel your lash on't.
Of your dear Nysa beguile ye—
Will but disgrace and defile ye
Are the measures fittest for ye.
Thus we gain the point we drive at

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE a Room in SILENO'S House. Daphne discovered at work.
Enter DAMAETAS, who sees her not.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Heigho! my very heart will burst asunder,
What star malign was I born under!
A muckworm herd
To me preferr'd,
O blood and thunder!
Ha, Daph, alone!—To silence
I'm aw'd—The Devil's in it.
Have at her—Here goes—.
Should she consent—who knows,
This may be the critical minute;
For ever lost a while hence!
Egad, I'm all agog on't.
Seize Time by the forelock,
E'en make a hog, or a dog on't;
The bolder push, the more luck.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Who sent for you, you hoddy doddy?

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: There, now, how cross!— (to her)
Nobody.
I came o'myself, as usual,
The question to pop.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Get you gone, you milk-sop;
What, after my refusal!

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Ah Daphne, you stop the breath o' me;
Hussey, you'll be the death o' me.
Ah, why, dear girl, why take up with that beggar,
And use your own Damaetas like a neger?
SP.STAGE: AIR XIV. Tune, Nanny of the Hill,

L.HI: Since first those eyes enslav'd my heart
My looks betray my inward smart,
Ah cruel! ah cruel! ah cruel, cruel Daph.
Inhuman maid, my sighs you scout,
My tears but make you laugh,
Yet at first sight, an upstart lout
Ah fickle! ah fickle! ah fickle, fickle Daph.
How can you on my courtship frown,
Yet suffer such a clumsy clown
To win and tickle, to win and tickle Daph.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.

LG.L: Who gave you leave my actions
Farther a field I weet you
For fear this beggar meet you

SP.STAGE: AIR XV. A French tune. Tourteulle.

L.HI: Yes; your wealth I hold at nought,
Daphne's heart shall ne'er be bought;
Would lock her up like his guinea.
In your pain my pleasure is,
Jealous dolt, I hate your phiz,

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Hey toss! Sh'as paid me soundly!
A swinging rap o'th' knuckles.
Well, to these honeysuckles
He's a meer oaf who truckles.
For miss the more he buckles
To, and will on ground lye,
The more curvetts and chuckles.
SP.STAGE: AIR XVI. Farewel the Hills and Vallies.

L.HI: His foe it is to push!
He's mad on death to rush.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Why—is the devil in you Gammer.
Have I no refuge from your clamour?

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Was ever wife so basely treated?
So cross'd, so gaul'd, so fretted!
O Gods! I shall run crazy
Mad, mad!

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: No March-hare madder,
Do, lambkin give it vent,—'twill ease you;
And make your heart the gladder.
SP.STAGE: AIR XVII. When that I was a little tiny Boy.

L.HI: When gathering clouds obscure the sky
The thunders rowl, and the lightnings fly;
So when a vixen's passions swell
Bosom rent by fiends of hell,
At length tears stream—and all is well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Well!—I'll be even with that spark yet.
Of fish a dainty kettle
You have drest—you numscul beetle;
You've brought your hogs to a fair market.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Why!—I'm all i'th' dark yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Know then thou peerless blockhead,
Your scoundrel, would he were choaked,
With his quips, and his quillets
And running his rigs
With both your daughters has intrigues
Nay here, read but these billets—

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Psha! put them in your pocket
Did not the sacred oak,

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: I mock it—

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Swear to me, on his conscience
That by Pol's means—

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: His means!—what nonsense!—
But I've a plot shall make you rue,
And keep the house too hot for you;
Don't be surpriz'd, if on the sudden,
Your minion give the crow a pudding
Soon mounted in the air, if
You chance to see the cudden
A caper cut before the sheriff.
SP.STAGE: AIR XVIII. To an Italian Opera tune.

L.HI: The wolf that slaughter'd finds her whelps,
Their murtherer tracks with shrillest yelps,

LG.L: So my revenge shall Pol pursue,

L.HI: 'Tll at the gallows tree he rue
The wrongs he did my daughters.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Gad's bud, I dread her vengeance
An angry woman to destroy
What she hates, would employ
The devil, and all his emgines.
Pol, here's a storm a brewing.
Old Pan, and our Mysis
Are hatching devices
To perpetrate your ruin.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Alas, what have I done—poor stranger!
Won't you protect me, sir, from danger?

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Tut, they shall find I ken 'em,
And on themselves can turn their venom,

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Poor fools! how weak, how shallow
Are all your plots against Apollo.
These clowns I pity—but my spleen 'twill pamper
Midas and Pan to hamper,
Their projects to quash
And their pride to abash,
When all my rays burst on them with one flash.
How I shall laugh, when huddled in a cluter,
They stare, gaping like stuck pigs at my lustre.
SP.STAGE: AIR XIX. When Faries dance round on the grass.

L.HI: When fairies dance round on the grass
And revel to night's awful noon,
Each elf with his tight little lass
Trips to the pale light of the moon,
If't chance that the grey dawn of day
Peep in on their frolicks too soon,
In fright they all scuttle away,
And follow the glimpse of the moon.

DIV2.STAGE: (As he is going off, enter Daphne on one side, Nysa on the other, both run to him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: O Pol! the fat's all in the fire!

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Such banging
In store for us.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: For you no less than hanging.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: The devil there is!—what means this sad haranguing?

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Fly, false deluder.

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Quick, take leg, deceitful—

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Take leg, and quit my girls! that were ungrateful.
SP.STAGE: AIR XX. To it's own tune.

L.HI: That it cannot find room for fear,
Such a love is not worth my care
For your vows are false as air.
What heart without shedding a tear,
I'd escort you with pleasure my dear,
What gallows so bad as despair.
Your falshood shall ne'er again grieve me.
Take my word, and my oath,
That at night I will satisfy both.
That at night I will satisfy both.
How, will you at night satisfy both?
No, you never can satisfy both.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III.
DIV2.STAGE: During the symphony, Mercury descends, and walks to and fro, tolling a bell, at intervals, as a public cryer; at the close, in broken air, he publishes the following advertisements.

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.

L.HI: O yes, O yes, O yes, this is to give notice.
Or reel'd down to earth, when maudlin,
As a switch tall and thin
Ne'er a rag to his skin,

SP.L: And answers to the name of Apollo.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Hush ribald cur, this bawling
Unless you wish a mawling!
Heaven's, what a sink of slander your foul throat is!

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.L: Oh are you there, master Apollo?
My elbow itch'd; I guess'd at what would follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Sirrah, you are a rogue beneath my notice.
SP.STAGE: AIR II. Kiss me fast my mother's coming.

L.HI: Worth disgrac'd dares hack and whittle
See the game cock's crest with mud upon't;
Strait the dunghill breed grows proud upon't,

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.L: Come come, let's buss, and friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Not 'till I curry your mungril hide.

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.L: Poo, let's shake hands, my hurry
Barr'd compliments.—Pray, pray, 'twas joke—I'm sorry.
Jove's in a raging fume, a pelting chafe!
Oh! 'tis such fun, would make even Pluto laugh!

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Do, let me know't.—I long, for his late kindness
To have him on the hip.

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.L: Hark then.—His highness,
Safe as he thought himself from your inquires,
Sruck up an assignation with Miss Iris:
Juno o'er heard it all—

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: —So had them track'd,
I do suppose, and caught them in the fact.

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.L: Ah, madam's an old hand:—she better judging,
Lock'd Iris up, and slipt into her lodging;
Lay snug—far'd well—ne'er cried, roast meat, but chuckled,
While old Twangdillo dub'd himself a cuckold.

L.HI: The Gods were all call'd in to see

LG.L: How fond a husband Jove could be:

L.HI: He strom'd; she laughed, yet, rouguishly
His fury rose to such a pitch,
He call'd her lewd, case-harden'd witch,
Swore, to his girls he'd stick like pitch,

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Oh I shall burst!—a pious resolution!
Means he to put it strait in execution?

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.L: Now, now; your pardon's sign'd; on double wages
You're to light up, and run, your usual stages:
So mount your box, old geeho, I advise you
Resume your task diurnal,
He threatens t' advertise you
In every weekly Journal.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Well, I've a wench, or two—you under∣stand me—
And a drole counter plot some knaves to catch,
Which in a trice, I will dispatch,
And then he may command me.

L.HI: Finds her spouse in her arms.
Cuckolds then will know their friends,
And, in like coin may make amends.
And cuckoo that word of fear,
Cuckolds then will know their friends
And cuckoo that word of fear,
And, in like coin may make amends

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE Midas's Parlour. Midas, Mysis, and Pan, discovered in consulta∣tion over a large bowl of punch, pipes and tobacco.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Come, Pan, your toast.—

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Here goes, our noble Umpire,

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: And Pol's defeat—I'll pledge it in a bum∣per.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Hang him, in every scheme that whelp has cross'd us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Sure he's the devil himself

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Or doctor Faustus.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Ah! Squire—for Pan wou'd you but stoutly stickle,
This Pol would soon be in a wretched pickle.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: You reason right—

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: His toby I shall tickle

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Look, Squire, I've sold my butter, here it's price is
At your command, do but this jobb for Mysis.
Count 'em.—Six guineas and an old jacobus
Keep Pan, and shame that scape-grace coram nous.

L.HI: Mark what I say you'll repent if
And not one job for a friend do?
Rouze up, nor thus your grave noddle shake,
We'll stick to Pan, his party take,

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: The justice in quandary!—Gad, we have him.—
Gammer, Pol's pipe is out; brandy can't save him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Goody, as 'tis your request,
I pocket this here stuff,
And, as for that there peasant,
Trust me, I'll work his buff.
At the musical struggle
I'll bully and juggle,
My award's
Your sure card,
Blood, he shall fly his country—that's enough.
SP.STAGE: AIR VI. To its own Tune.

L.HI: If in the courts your suit depend,
Or a cause you'd fain do hurt in,
Be sure you make the judge your friend
By a tip behind the curtain.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Well said, my lad of wax—since you're so mettled
I'll have one tryal with this fop—that's settled.
A word i' your ear—You'll find it no hard matter,
When she'as lost Pol, to nab our crony's daughter.

L.HI: As soon as her doating piece fairly is sped,
Do you make your push, and a stout one:
For now she has got a sweetheart in her head,
She'll never be easy without one;
Rever'd by the shepherds, caress'd by the nymphs,
No dread or remorse shall come o'er us,
At sessions, in spite of the law and its imps,
We'll kick the whole country before us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Ha! ha! sit down, and make an end o'th' tankard,
I have no head for business till I've drank hard.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Nor have my brains guts in them till they're addle,
When I'm most rocky I best sit my saddle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: I always chuck a priming at the tap, or
A cogue of Nantzy, just to oil my clapper.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Well come, let's take one bouze, and roar a catch,
Then part to our affairs.—

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: A match.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: A catch.

DIV2.STAGE: AIR VIII. A Catch. Cold and Raw.

L.HI: I'll buffet away from our plain, sir;
With all my might and main, sir;
And makes such a woundy racket.
And I warrant we pepper his jackett.

SP.SPEAKER: Cho.
SP.L: I'll bluff, &c.

L.HI: He shall rue on his knees 'em,
And I with my davy will back it;

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.

L.HI: And I'll warrant we pepper his jacket.

SP.L: Chor. I'll swear, I'll snare, &c.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE Discovers Sileno and Damaetas in warm argu∣ment, on the lawn before Midas's house.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: My Daphne a wife for thee! the squire's base Pandar!
To the plantations sooner would I send her.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Sir, your good wife approv'd my offers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Name her not, Hag of Endor,
What knew she of thee but by thy coffers?

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: And shall this ditch-born whelp, this jackanapes.
By dint of congees and scrapes—

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: These are thy slanders and that canker'd hag's.—

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: A thing made up of pilfer'd rags—

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Richer than thou with all thy brags
Of flocks, and herds, and money bags.

L.HI: If a rival thy character draw
In perfection he'll find cut flaw,
Make a devil of a saint
And change to an Owl a Maccaw.
Can a father pretend to be wise
Who his friend's good advice will despise?
And blinks thro' a green girl's eyes?
Your an impudent pimp and a grub,
You are fool'd by a beggarly scrub;
Who will lend me a club,
Your an impudent pimp and a grub,
Your cajol'd by a beggarly scrub
Who will rot in a powdering tub,
Whom the prince of impostor's I dub;
When you find that your cub
Rub off, sirrah, rub, sirrah, rub.
Is debauch'd by a whip'd syllabub.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mysis attended by Dapne and Nysa.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Soh!—you attend the tryal,—we shall drive hence
Your vagabond—

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: I smoke your foul contrivance

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Ah Ny, our fate depends upon this issue—

SP.SPEAKER: Nys Daph.
SP.L: —for your sake, my claim I here forgo.
And with your Pol, much joy I wish you.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: O, gemini, say'st thou me so?
Dear creature let me kiss you.

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Let's kneel, and beg his stay, papa will back us.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Mama will storm,

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: What then, she can but whack us.

DIV2.STAGE: AIR XI. Quintetto. Viens que I'Examine-a-

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: He's so charming, &c.

L.HI: Sluts, are you lost to shame?

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Must Pan resign, to this fop, his em∣ployment?
Must, I, to him, yield of Daph. the enjoyment?

L.HI: Ne'er while a tongue I brandish,

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Midas must judge

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: And Pol must fly

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Zounds, Pol shan't budge,

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Pan's drone is fit for wild rocks and bleak mountains

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Pol's lyre suits best our cool groves and clear fountains.

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Pol is young and merry

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Pan is old and rusty

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Can you banish Pol?

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Let Pan fall

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Must Pan resign, to this fop, his em∣ployment?

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Pan 's drone is fit for wild rocks and bleak mountains

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Must I to Pol, yield of Daph. the enjoyment?

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Pol 's lyre suits best our cool groves and clear fountains.

L.HI: Ne'er while a tongue I brandish

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Pol is young and merry

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Pan is old and rusty.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Daph shall blandish

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Can you banish Pol?

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Midas must judge,

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: And Pol must fly

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Pray let Pan fall,

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Zounds, Pol shan't budge

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Blood, Pan shall go

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Poor Pan! poor I!

DIV2.STAGE: Midas comes forth enrag'd, attended by a crowd of Nymphs and Swains.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Peace ho! is hell broke loose? what means this jawing?
Under my very nose this clapper clawing!

L.HI: What the devil's here to do
And each of you tipsey is.
But I'll sure pull down your pride as

LG.L: A gun, or as I'm justice Midas.
Who shall oppose wise justice Midas

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: I'm given to understand that your all in a pother here
Disputing whether Pan or Pol, shall play to you another year.
Dare you think your clumsey lungs so proper to decide as
The delicate ears of justice Midas?

SP.SPEAKER: Cho.
SP.L: O Tremendous, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Soh! you allow it then—Ye mobbish rabble?
Oh, here comes Pol, and Pan—now stint your gabble.
Fetch my great chair—I'll quickly end this squabble.
SP.STAGE: AIR XIII. To it's own tune.

L.HI: Like the sophi on his throne
Shall not call their souls their own.
But be transported like a thief.

SP.SPEAKER: Cho.
SP.L: O Tremendous, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Masters, will you abide by this condi∣tion,

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: I ask no better

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: —I am all submission.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Strik up, sweet Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: —Sir, I attend your leisure

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Pan, take the lead,

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: —Since 'tis your worship's plea∣sure.

L.HI: A pox of your pother about this or that,
Your shrieking or squeaking sharp or a flat;
I'm sharp by my bumpers, you're flat, master Pol,
So here goes a set-to at Toll de roll loll.
When Beauty her pack of poor lovers would hamper,
And after miss Will o' the Wisp the fools scamper,
Ding dong, in sing song, they the lady extol;

LG.L: Pray what's all this fuss for, but—Toll de roll, &c.

L.HI: Mankind are a medley—a chance-medley race,
All start in full cry to give dame Fortune chace;
There's catch as catch can, hit or miss Luck is all,
And Luck's the best tune of life's Toll lol de roll.
I've done, please your worship, 'tis rather too long,
I only meant life is but an old song;
The world's but a tragedy, comedy, droll,
Where all act the scene of Toll loll de rol lol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: By jingo, well perform'd for one of his age;
How, hang dog, don't you blush to shew your visage?

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Why, master Midas, for that matter,
'Tis enough to dash one,
To hear the arbitrator,
In such unseemly fashion
One of the candidates bespatter
With so much partial passion.

L.HI: But, from her charms when sunder'd,
Each hour will seem an hundred,

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Silence—this just decree all, at your peril
Obedient hear,—else I shall use you very ill.
Oh tremendous, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: All bow with me to mighty Pan—en∣throne him.—
No pouting—and with festal chorus crown him!—
SP.STAGE: [The crowd forms two ranks beside the chair, and join in the chorus, whilst Midas crowns him with bays.]

LG.L: Crown'd with bays, his due reward.
While, with ecchoing shouts of praise

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: 'Tis well!—what keeps you here—you ragamuffin?
Go trudge—or do you wait for a good cuffing?

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Now, listen all—The wrath of Jove, for rapine,
Corruption, lust, pride, fraud, there's no escaping.
Tremble, thou wretch—Thou'st stretch'd thy ut∣most tether,
Thou, and thy tools shall go to pot together.

L.HI: God of music and king of Parnass:
I reward with the ears of an ass.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Detected, baulk'd, and small,
On our marrow bones we fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Detected, baulk'd, and small,
On our marrow bones we fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Detected, baulk'd, and small,
On our marrow bones we fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Mys.
SP.L: Be merciful,
Alas, alas!

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Be pitiful,
Alas, alas!

SP.SPEAKER: Mid.
SP.L: Forgive us, mighty Sol,
Alas, alas!

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.

L.HI: With, strumpets and bailiffs shall class.

SP.L: He a stinking old goat, thou an ass, an ass, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Mid., Mys., Dam.
SP.L: Alas! Alas!

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Now my heart's cur'd of folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: —Be jolly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: The Oracle's word
For millions should pass.
Mysis is well parted,

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: And the pimp carted,

SP.SPEAKER: Nys.
SP.L: Squire. Midas converted
Into an ass, O the dull ass!

SP.SPEAKER: Daph., Sil., Mys., Dam., Apollo.
SP.STAGE: All together, but to several airs, while Midas joins in chorus, braying like an ass.
SP.L: Into an ass, laugh at the ass!
Into an ass, a real ass!
What a sad ass,
Alas, alas!
Be thou an ass.

SP.SPEAKER: Apol.
SP.L: Be thou squire—his estate to Sil.
To thee I translate.
To you his strong chests, wicked mass, to Daph. & Nysa.
Live happy, while I,
Recall'd to the sky,
Make all the Gods laugh at Midas.

SP.SPEAKER: Apol., Dam., Mid., Mys., Daph., Nys., Sil.
SP.L: All the Gods laugh at Midas.
Alas, Alas! Exit.
[Goes about braying like an ass]
What a sad pass—Ah, poor Midas.
Chang'd to an ass—Well bray'd Midas.
Well bray'd Midas; manifest ass.
Laugh at the ass; laugh at the ass.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph., Sil., Nys.
SP.STAGE: Together, with the other nymphs and swains.
SP.L: To the bright God of day
Let us dance, sing, and play,
Clap hands every lad with his 'lass.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.L: Now criticks lye snug,
Not a hiss, groan, or shrug,
Remember the fate of Midas, Midas,
Remember the fate of Midas.
Now criticks lye snug, &c.
